channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Israel, Race Between Netanyahu and Herzog Appears Too Close to Call
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his chief challenger, Isaac Herzog, appeared to win about the same number of seats in Parliament on Tuesday, according to Israeli media and exit polls.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Netanyahu Expresses Alarm That Arab Voter Turnout Could Help Unseat Him
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Arab voters “streaming in huge quantities to the polling stations” could determine the election’s outcome.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S.-Cuba Talks on Restoring Diplomatic Ties End Abruptly
item.description: State Department officials arrived in Havana on Sunday and left Monday even as both sides had hoped to have date for reopening embassies before a regional meeting in Panama next month.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: France, Germany and Italy Say They’ll Join China-Led Bank in Rebuff to U.S.
item.description: The three countries said they would be part of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which Washington views as a rival to the World Bank.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Iranians Issue Upbeat Assessment of Nuclear Talks; Americans Are More Cautious
item.description: The statements came as the March-end deadline nears for a framework agreement on limiting Iran’s disputed nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Remains in Madrid Are Believed to Be Those of Cervantes
item.description: Spanish investigators said they had reason to believe that bones found at the Convent of the Discalced Trinitarians were those of the “Don Quixote” author.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Forensics experts examined the subsoil from a convent in Madrid in January. Investigators said on Tuesday that some of the remains of Cervantes are believed to be among the samples.

item.title: Syrian Activists Say Chlorine Gas Attack Kills 6 in Idlib Province
item.description: The Assad government denied the report, but activists posted video online of medics in gas masks dousing victims with water and of children in hospitals.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Family Drama Entangles Hong Kong’s Leader
item.description: Leung Chun-ying, Hong Kong’s chief executive, denied his daughter’s allegations that her mother had abused her and confined her to the family’s residence.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Leung Chai-yan, the daughter of the Hong Kong chief executive, Leung Chun-ying, on Saturday at the amfAR gala for AIDS research.

item.title: As Argentina and Hedge Funds Battle, Citigroup Bows Out
item.description: The bank cited an “unprecedented international conflict of laws” that prevented it from making interest payments to Argentine bondholders.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:description: Judge Thomas P. Griesa of the Federal District Court in Manhattan has prevented Citigroup from making interest payments to investors holding Argentine notes.

item.title: United Nations Workers Accused of Sexual Abuse
item.description: A report’s findings showed that the bulk of the cases involved peacekeepers deployed to some of the most troubled parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Fatima Bhutto: Don’t Execute Shafqat Hussain
item.description: The pending execution of a man falsely accused of murder when he was 14 shows the folly of the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: FATIMA BHUTTO
item.media:description: A relative holding a photo of Shafqat Hussain, earlier this month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: David Shambaugh on the Risks to Chinese Communist Rule
item.description: The highly influential American scholar of Chinese politics argues that his recent essay about the ‘‘endgame’’ of the Communist Party envisions a protracted period of decline.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: South Korea Tells China Not to Meddle in Decision Over Missile System
item.description: Beijing has been pressing its neighbor to reject Washington’s calls to install a missile defense system, prompting Seoul to deliver a rare public retort.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Detention of Rights Activists in China Soared in 2014, Report Says
item.description: Those held encompass a wide group of people, including opponents of sexual discrimination, groups pushing for migrant workers’ rights and those who argue for better treatment of ethnic minorities.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Lun Chunxia, a supporter of the lawyer and rights advocate Xu Zhiyong, being detained by the police near a Beijing court where Mr. Xu's trial was underway on Jan. 22, 2014.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: ‘Top Gear’ Hits Rock Bottom
item.description: Our public culture is sadly diminished if the boorish BBC TV presenter Jeremy Clarkson is seen as a champion of free speech.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK
item.media:description: Jeremy Clarkson at a soccer match earlier this month, in London.

item.title: Israel Elections: The Vote and Results
item.description: Israel holds national elections Tuesday to determine if Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his Likud Party will earn a third consecutive term, or if the Zionist Union, led by Isaac Herzog and Tzipi Livni, will garner enough seats to form a new government.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Myanmar Sentences 3 to Prison for Depicting Buddha Wearing Headphones
item.description: A bar manager from New Zealand and two Burmese men, including the bar’s owner, had posted the image to promote an event and received two-year terms.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Soe Than Win/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Philip Blackwood, a bar manager from New Zealand, leaving court on Tuesday. Mr. Blackwood and two Burmese men were sentenced to two years in prison in Myanmar for posting an image online of the Buddha wearing headphones to promote an event.

item.title: Afghan Militia Leaders, Empowered by U.S. to Fight Taliban, Inspire Fear in Villages
item.description: The leaders, brought to power amid an American counterinsurgency strategy, continue to rule villages, where people say the militias have turned to kidnappings and extortion.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Afghan Local Police from Kandahar preparing for a mission in 2013 in Zhare district. While some of these units are fighting with discipline, other militias that the Americans helped create have a reputation for abuse and banditry.

item.title: Vanuatu Death Toll Is Likely to Rise as Glimpses of Cyclone’s Fury Emerge
item.description: Accounts trickling in from remote islands indicate widespread devastation to crops and homes in the wake of Tropical Cyclone Pam, relief workers said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Iran Sent Arms to Iraq to Fight ISIS, U.S. Says
item.description: American officials fear the rockets and missiles could further inflame sectarian tensions and cause civilian casualties because they are not precision-guided.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: United States intelligence officials say that Fateh-110 missiles, like this one displayed in 2010 in Tehran, were sent to Iraq.
